microtool.optimize package¶

Submodules¶

microtool.optimize.loss_functions module¶

class microtool.optimize.loss_functions.CrlbBase(information_func: Callable[[ndarray, ndarray, float], ndarray])¶

Bases: LossFunction, ABC

Base class for CRLB-based loss functions. This bass class is made because checking of the fisher information matrix is the same for all crlb based loss functions. We ensure that derived classes can actually compute crlb by abstractmethod.

abstract static compute_crlb(information: ndarray) → float¶

Computes the cramer roa lower bound based loss given the fisher information (assumed well conditioned)

Parameters:

information – A well conditioned fisher information matrix

Returns:

loss

class microtool.optimize.loss_functions.CrlbEigenvalues(information_func: Callable[[ndarray, ndarray, float], ndarray])¶

Bases: CrlbBase

static compute_crlb(information: ndarray) → float¶

Computes the crlb-based loss using eigenvalues of the information matrix. For proof see appendix of notes

Parameters:

information – Fisher information matrix of shape N,N

Returns:

The crlb based loss

class microtool.optimize.loss_functions.CrlbInversion(information_func: Callable[[ndarray, ndarray, float], ndarray])¶

Bases: CrlbBase

static compute_crlb(information: ndarray) → float¶

Computes the crlb-based loss by inverting the information matrix

Parameters:

information – Fisher information matrix of shape (N,N) where N is number of parameters in model

Returns:

crlb-based loss

class microtool.optimize.loss_functions.LossFunction¶

Bases: ABC

Base class for lossfunctions, just to ensure call signature constant between different loss functions

microtool.optimize.loss_functions.compute_loss(scheme: AcquisitionScheme, model: TissueModel, noise_var: float, loss: LossFunction) → float¶

Function for computing the loss given the following parameters

Parameters:

  • model – The tissuemodel for which you wish to know the loss

  • scheme – The acquisition scheme for which you wish to know the loss

  • noise_var – The scaling factor of the noise distribution

  • loss – The loss function

Returns:

The loss value associated with this model and scheme

microtool.optimize.loss_functions.fisher_information_gauss(jac: ndarray, signal: ndarray, noise_var: float) → ndarray¶

Calculates the Fisher information matrix, assuming Gaussian noise. This is the sum of the matrices of squared gradients, for all samples, divided by the noise variance. See equation A2 in Alexander, 2008 (DOI 0.1002/mrm.21646)

Parameters:

  • signal –

  • jac – An N×M Jacobian matrix, where N is the number of samples and M is the number of parameters.

  • noise_var – Noise variance.

Returns:

The M×M information matrix.

microtool.optimize.loss_functions.fisher_information_rice(jac: ndarray, signal: ndarray, noise_var: float) → ndarray¶

Calculates the fisher information matrix assuming Rician noise.

The integral term can be approximated up to 4% as reported in https://doi.org/10.1109/TIT.1967.1054037 :param signal: :param jac: :param noise_var: :return:

microtool.optimize.loss_functions.scipy_loss(x: ndarray, scheme: AcquisitionScheme, model: TissueModel, noise_variance: float, loss: LossFunction, scaling_factor: float = 1.0) → float¶

Wraps the compute loss function, where we use the API of AcquisitionScheme to set the acquisition parameters to the optimizers’ desired values.

Parameters:

  • x – The acquisiton parameter vector provided by scipy optimization (so scaled values in an np.ndarray)

  • scheme – The AcquisitionScheme

  • model – The TissueModel

  • noise_variance – The noise shape parameter (variance for gaussian)

  • loss – The loss function to be used in optimization

  • scaling_factor – The factor by which the output of the loss function is scaled

Returns:

The loss value associated with parameters above.

Executes a single population migration

Parameters:

  • path_length – The path an individual will follow

  • N_jump – Number of jumps along the path

  • PRT – Probability of accepting a step vector

class microtool.optimize.methods.SOMA(population_sz: int = 50, max_migrations: int = 200, max_fevals=None, PRT: float = 0.1, path_length: float = 3.0, step: float = 0.11)¶

Bases: Optimizer

A class for defining a classic all to one soma algorithm. The __call__ method executes the algorithm The other class methods are made to initialize all parts of the algorithm with control parameters defined on initialization. Visit https://ivanzelinka.eu/somaalgorithm/About.html for the more information on this algorithm and codes for which this implementation is the source.

microtool.optimize.methods.is_constrained(x: ndarray, constraint: dict) → bool¶

A function for checking if a given parameter combination breaks a given constraint.

Parameters:

  • constraint – A scipy compatible constraint dictionary

  • x – Parameter combination

Returns:

boolean that is true if the parameter combination breaks the constraint

microtool.optimize.optimize module¶

microtool.optimize.optimize.bounds_tuple2scipy(microtool_bounds: List[Tuple[float, float]]) → Bounds¶
microtool.optimize.optimize.check_degrees_of_freedom(scheme: AcquisitionScheme, model: TissueModel)¶
microtool.optimize.optimize.check_ill_conditioned(loss_value: float)¶
microtool.optimize.optimize.check_insensitive(scheme: AcquisitionScheme, model: TissueModel)¶
microtool.optimize.optimize.optimize_scheme(scheme: ~microtool.optimize.optimize.AcquisitionType, model: ~microtool.tissue_model.TissueModel, noise_variance: float, loss: ~microtool.optimize.loss_functions.LossFunction = <microtool.optimize.loss_functions.CrlbEigenvalues object>, loss_scaling_factor: float = 1.0, method: str | ~microtool.optimize.methods.Optimizer | None = 'differential_evolution', solver_options: dict | None = None) → Tuple[AcquisitionType, OptimizeResult | None]¶

Optimizes the free parameters in the given MR acquisition scheme such that the loss is minimized. The loss function should be of type LossFunction, which takes an N×M Jacobian matrix, an array with M parameter scales, and the noise variance. The loss function should return a scalar loss. N is the number of measurements in the acquisition and M is the number of tissue parameters.

Parameters:

  • scheme – The MR acquisition scheme to be optimized. (NOTE: a reference of the scheme is passed, so it will be changed.

  • model – The tissuemodel for which we want the optimal acquisition scheme.

  • noise_variance – Noise variance on the MR signal attenuation.

  • loss – a function of type LossFunction.

  • loss_scaling_factor – Can be used to scale the loss function to order 1.0 if you notice extreme values.

  • method – Type of solver. See the documentation for scipy.optimize.minimize

  • solver_options – Options specific to the solver check the documentation of the solver to see what can be done.

Returns:

A scipy.optimize.OptimizeResult object.

microtool.optimize.optimize.warn_early_termination(result: OptimizeResult)¶
